FEjqq7kUEG_xqqaR6wg-VA.text: Had the coconut  mushroom pasta  Really good , a little less garlic would have been great ,Excellent staff , pretty decor Good lunch place :)

qhwRTDmfjq6Wav0ck4LjOg.text: Great food, and amazing drinks. Their coconut milk mocktail was fantastic. Safe bet for some amazing food with the family, quiet setting and free wi-fi.

photos.caption: Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore

XWmgnxEuvuV-uprTxkfpww.text: 2.5 stars. This place is ok if you're in the area. My friend and I ordered the chili crab buns to start and both us ordered our own pasta dish. The buns were flavorful and I could've just ordered buns for my meal and been happy. The pasta was just ok, I had the lemon shrimp pasta. It felt like it was missing something. Our waitress was sweet but a bit ditzy. We didn't have bad service but we didn't have excellent service either so in Singapore that means it's alright.

photos.caption: Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore

svzpZH53uNvcq8cQ9qoeVw.text: Good place for a drink on their patio. They carry guest taps and I was impressed with them having Anderson Valley on tap (no, I didn't order it)!

H2cbk7OpW6rttoOa4Fn7FQ.text: Girlfriends and I were enjoying a nice get-together over good food. We started with a pumpkin soup which was velvety and flavourful! Loved it! We then ordered 4 different pastas (Mushroom Risotto, Sun-dried Tomato Pasta , Carbonara and Seafood Linguine) and they all tasted pretty good actually!Ladies MUST have desserts so we had 3 to share. We ordered Red Velvet Deluxe, Bailey's Extraordinary and Double Decker Mud Cake. I appreciated that their desserts are not the run-of-the-mill type and good tasting too!With starter, soup, main, dessert and tea, the bill came up to about $30 per pax which I thought is very decent. Definitely a revisit when in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Red Velvet
Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Extraordinary Baileys
Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Double-Decker Mud Cake

gi3iQegJn067kBYV0HaNhg.text: I came for the crustacean bowl as I read a review about it online. Not worth it. Your first drink is $6, worth it. Crustacean bowl 2/5 - the description proved to be more exciting than the dish itself. The dish is basically rice, a LOT of cheese, and lobster bits sitting in a little bit of broth. Cheese was overwhelming, causing the lobster to lose all its flavor. Rice was in broth turned into a bad risotto.Strawberry dust drink 4/5 - not bad for $6. Basically a strawberry margarita with less acidity. Outside of the whole class is covered in chocolate powder. Cool, but impractical unless you plan on licking the glass and your chocolate-stained fingers.Ambience - fresh, light, modern. Nice.

photos.caption: Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Crustacean bowl $27.5
Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Strawberry dust $6
Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Crustacean bowl $27.5

GIopwggyeC8YjacEkE0IpQ.text: Decently cooked pasta dishes and Mediterranean inspired fare. They try to be a bit adventurous with the fusion approach to some dishes so you get tobikko, dried Japanese chilli shreds and nori strips sprinkled with a liberal hand. But I'm ok with that.My friends love the crab cakes (decent with not too much filler for the price range and lightly crisp). They're a bit understaffed tho and given the crowds they need to hire more waiters.

photos.caption: Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Crab and tobikko bucatini. Nice combination
Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Spicy crab and prawn Diablo.
Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Crispy crab cakes. Light and not greasy.

utBw_NWP8SVyHHTaNdYL0g.text: Meet a couple of friends there and the food was decent. Started off with the soups, had the pumpkin and lobster which were both flavourful and could not complain. My girlfriend had the salmon ikura don which was creative and well done. Salmon was pink, the broth was a perfect fit to the rice. Great dish. I had the "korean" chicken. Very juicy and flavourful but the fries were a fail in my opinion. Soaked in oil. But overall filling and not a bad dish as well. The desserts were a slight letdown. The panna cotta lacked flavour. The berry was good and tangy but the jelly itself was lacking. I personally did not like the ice cream and our friends had the molten lava cake which was too sweet in their opinion. Decent place and great for a casual gathering with friends.

Ar-KsuQP9zefINQ7jpIC0Q.text: By default ended up at Platypus Kitchen because we could not get reservations at Platypus Lobster. Although Victoria Street is a sweet area for dining, shopping, and people watching; their Platypus Lobster location is a bit higher rated....whatever.1st  *nice location2nd *quickly seated3rd *great drink menu. First specialty drink$6.000      Wtf service 0      destroying the New England Lobster Roll. "Shame, shame, shame"

xD8sYMN8WTL__EI8-jnNEw.text: Arrrrg we had a strange dining experience last Saturday. Let's preface with the positive parts before the "what the heck?" moments surface.The menu at Platypus Kitchen is interesting but still chock full of sellers. By sellers I mean dishes you know the average Singaporean will like, think eggs benedict for brunch places, words like "soft shell crab", "foie gras" and "truffle fries" on lunch and dinner menus in Western restaurants. Platypus does away with the usual and instead peppers its menu with homemade pastas in sauces that sound familiar but aren't boring, crab cakes (which for some reason "wasn't being sold anymore") and ok fine, the ubiquitous truffle fries. The dude and I ordered off the set dinner menu: garden salads, I had the diablo crab & prawn bucatini (fat spaghetti basically) while he had the duck confit and we finished with the caramel cake and warm apple tart. The salads were fresh and had a wonderfully tangy dressing that was just delightful to eat. No, I didn't need to pick out brown or wilting leaves or sigh at how my salad was swimming in dressing. None of that. My pasta was fresh, cooked al dente and the sauce was light, full of flavor and supposedly egg based though I couldn't taste it (in a good way). The dude enjoyed his duck confit as well.So where did things go downhill? To start with, the waitress taking our orders seemed rather snappy and cut both of us off midway while ordering. For example, we told her our mains and as we were about to mention our dessert choices she said "Oh so you're having 2 courses ah?" as opposed to listening or perhaps a more genial "would you like some desserts with that for a few extra bucks". Then, the dude's duck confit was served while we were about 2 mouthfuls into our salads. Ummm..no. The waiter that served the dishes was also in such a hurry to get away that he literally put the dishes on our table and zoomed off. So here we are rushing to eat our food so it doesn't get cold. We finished it and we waited with our table cluttered with empty salad and main dishes. And we waited. It seemed like the entire crew was hanging out at the bar counter chatting and our desserts were no where in sight. When we finally got their attention and the desserts, I received the strangest "frozen" caramel cake. It was very cold and the sponge layer dry, such that I found it difficult to eat. Seriously me, the dessert lover rejecting a cake? Uh huh. I asked the waitress if the cake was fresh because it seemed stale and she said "yes it's meant to be a frozen cake". Alright then, remember NOT to order the caramel hunk of coldness. It's a pity because the dude's apple tart was great and we suspect the caramel cake, served with care, would've been great too.To end things off, while we were eating said desserts, the cashier came over and asked us to check our bill. We checked it and realized she was still standing there expectantly so we asked, "is something wrong?" to which she replied that she would like us to pay the bill now because she was closing the counter. *Throws hands in the air and headdesks*The cashier did the same thing to every other table in the restaurant (which was about 1/3 full and no one was done eating) and processed the bills in a batch. We were done eating at some point during that batch processing and had to wait. Again. For our check, which we were forced to pay before we finished eating. And to end things, we asked for a feedback form and objectively gave our comments. One of the waiters however, felt the need to read the comment form with the rest of the team BEFORE we left the restaurant or got our credit card back. The upside was the cashier came back and apologized and took 10% off our bill. The downside is I was just completely flabbergasted at why any service team would do that and I'm pretty sure my comments didn't make it to the management team.To conclude, I hope we got a very outlier experience at Platypus Kitchen because if this is the norm, I don't know how it will stay in business. Just because I don't enjoy being rushed AND ignored, I am not returning anytime soon even though I enjoyed the food.  To the service team, I've been a waitress before as a student for several years and it isn't hard to do your job at least marginally well. Take pride in what you do!

sn9pGazER2pTFHtHLWdYgA.text: This place has pretty good ambience and dim lightings. It's popz for its variety of handmade pastas. I ordered a set - mushroom soup, pomegranate tea and Spicy 'Diablo' crab & prawn pasta.Can't go wrong with the soup and pomegranate tea is pretty rare in sg. It reminded me of Turkish apple tea somehow. Pasta is interesting: Egg tagliolini - looks like Chinese egg meepok (sorry for the lack of adjectives.) it was topped with crab claw meat and prawns. But crab claw meat had lotsa hidden garlic-look-alike inside so if you like garlic this might be ur cup of tea. Oh the spicy egg sauce is not so spicy.Aircon was on full blast so my pasta got cold real quick. Overall, the food taste decent but I still prefer traditional pasta. But come here if u wanna try fusion and variety! :)

photos.caption: Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Spicy 'Diablo' crab and prawn
Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Lemon prawn pappardelle
Photo of Platypus Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Mushroom and pumpkin soup

n297LAuM03miZJCVpcxYrw.text: Good food at affordable price. The ingredients that they used made me feel that good food actually doesn't mean it's expensive. You paid for the chef's name... back to the food. I LOVE their pumkin soup topped with grilled bacons and cheddar cheese. Very creamy and simply delicious. I tried their lobster pasta ( cant remember the name exactly) it's good but a little salty. Probably cos I asked for half the pasta? Their duck confit is good. The dessert is so so.nothing special about that.
